name: Matera
fun_fact: Fun fact: Matera is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world, with cave dwellings (Sassi) that have been occupied for over 9,000 years since the Paleolithic era. It's the only place where people still live in the same houses as their ancestors from 9,000 years ago!

hero_dishes.name: Pane di Matera IGP
hero_dishes.description: Iconic durum wheat bread with Protected Geographical Indication status, featuring an intensely thick crust and tangy, chewy interior with large irregular holes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Made using rare Lucanian-milled semolina grain (Senatore Cappelli) and natural yeast from grapes and figs fermented in local spring water. The long fermentation process creates the signature sourdough-like taste and keeps the bread fresh for up to a week.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Bakeries tucked into the Sassi cave dwellings are best for authentic IGP-certified loaves. Look for official certification guaranteeing the real experience.

hero_dishes.name: Fave e Cicoria
hero_dishes.description: Traditional soup of mashed fava beans, wild chicory leaves, and sundried peppers - a humble peasant dish showcasing Basilicata's agricultural heritage
hero_dishes.origin_story: This dish represents centuries-old traditions of making simple, local ingredients into nourishing meals in the harsh cave-dwelling environment.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Lopa (small cave restaurant), Baccanti (high-end interpretation on stone terrace or in subterranean cave)

hero_dishes.name: Crapiata
hero_dishes.description: Ancient soup made from beans and grains, following recipes passed down for generations
hero_dishes.origin_story: A traditional harvest celebration dish that reflects the agrarian culture of the Materan countryside.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Lopa, traditional trattorie in the Sassi

hero_dishes.name: Peperoni Cruschi
hero_dishes.description: Crispy sun-dried peppers - crunchy, sweet, and slightly smoky. Known as 'red gold' of Basilicata
hero_dishes.origin_story: A staple of Basilicata cuisine, these preserved peppers allowed families to enjoy summer's harvest through the winter months in the caves.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served as appetizers or garnish at most traditional restaurants; found at markets throughout Matera

hero_dishes.name: Pignata
hero_dishes.description: Stewed meat with vegetables prepared in a ceramic pot, slow-cooked following centuries-old traditions
hero_dishes.origin_story: The name comes from the terracotta pot it's cooked in. This dish was ideal for cave-dwelling families who needed meals that could cook slowly while they worked.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional restaurants in the Sassi, Regiacorte

signature_drinks.name: Vino Primitivo di Matera
signature_drinks.description: Bold red wine made from Primitivo grapes grown in the Matera terroir
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with aged cheeses, lamb dishes, and the region's hearty peasant food. The wine reflects the intense sun and limestone soil of the Murgia plateau.

signature_drinks.name: Aglianico del Vulture
signature_drinks.description: Powerful red wine from the nearby Vulture region, considered one of Southern Italy's finest wines
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals pair this age-worthy wine with grilled meats and sharp pecorino cheese, especially during Sunday family meals.

food_culture_notes: Matera's cuisine is cucina povera (peasant cooking) elevated to art - simple ingredients treated with respect and centuries of knowledge
The Sassi cave environment influenced cooking methods: slow-cooked stews, preserved foods, and bread that stays fresh for days
Orecchiette and cavatelli pastas are shaped by hand, often served with lamb ragÃ¹ or cime di rapa (turnip tops)
Over 150 rupestrian (rock-carved) churches from Byzantine monks dot the landscape, blending Eastern and Western religious traditions
Breakfast culture: locals dip thick slices of Pane di Matera into espresso or spread with fresh ricotta and honey
